review.title: Semi-Supervised Learning for Detecting Human Trafficking
review.abstract: Human trafficking is one of the most atrocious crimes and among the challenging problems facing law enforcement which demands attention of global magnitude. In this study, we leverage textual data from the website "Backpage"- used for classified advertisement- to discern potential patterns of human trafficking activities which manifest online and identify advertisements of high interest to law enforcement. Due to the lack of ground truth, we rely on a human analyst from law enforcement, for hand-labeling a small portion of the crawled data. We extend the existing Laplacian SVM and present S3VM-R, by adding a regularization term to exploit exogenous information embedded in our feature space in favor of the task at hand. We train the proposed method using labeled and unlabeled data and evaluate it on a fraction of the unlabeled data, herein referred to as unseen data, with our expert's further verification. Results from comparisons between our method and other semi-supervised and supervised approaches on the labeled data demonstrate that our learner is effective in identifying advertisements of high interest to law enforcement

metadata.title: Semi-Supervised Learning for Detecting Human Trafficking

sections.text: Keywords: Trafficking · Back · Semi-Supervised Support Vector Machines · Laplacian Support Vector Machines

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to survive on their own, without being able to survive on their own.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: In recent years, the number of people who are able to survive in the US has multiplied, not only in the US, but also in other parts of the world.

sections.heading: 3 Data Preparation
sections.text: Each entry contains a title, a description, a timestamp, the age of the poster, the poster ID, the location, the image and sometimes also video and audio. The description usually briefly lists the attributes of the person (s) and the phone numbers. In this work, we focus only on the textual component of the data. These free text data required significant cleaning due to a variety of problems common in text analysis (i.e. misspelling, the format of the phone numbers, etc.). We also acknowledge that the information in the data may be intentionally inaccurate, such as the poster name, age and even physical appearance (e.g. the size of the bra body, weight). Figure 1 shows an actual contribution from Backpage.com. To illustrate the geographical diversity of the listings, we use Tableau1 software to visualize the potential frequency of advertising in relation to the various states in Figure 2, with a higher number of female performers.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Advertisement Language Pattern
sections.text: The first group consists of various linguistic characteristics. For the first and second characteristics, we identify posts that have the language of the third person (which are morelikely written by someone other than the companion) and posts that contain plural pronouns of the first person such as "we" and "our" (which are more likely to be an organization) [6]. To ensure their anonymity, traffickers would use techniques to generate diverse information and thus make their posts appear more complicated. They usually do this in order to avoid being identified by human analysts or automated programs. [25] So, to obtain the third characteristic, we take an approach from the complexity theory, namely the Kolmogorov complexity, which is defined as the length of the shortest program to reproduce a string of characters on a universal machine such as the Turning Machine. [25] Since the Kolmogorov complexity is unpredictable, we approach the complexity of a value by first removing the contents of an ad and then the ent25 entries.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 Words and Phrases of Interest
sections.text: Although the advertisement on Backpage.com does not directly mention sex with children, customers who prefer children know how to search for words and phrases such as "sweet, sweet, fresh, new in town, new in the game." [27,28, 29] We therefore examine within the posts whether they contain words that could be highly related to human trafficking in general.

sections.heading: 3.1.3 Countries of Interest
sections.text: We can see if the person being accompanied comes from other countries, such as Southeast Asia (especially China, Vietnam, Korea and Thailand, as we have observed in our data) [3].

sections.heading: 3.1.4 Multiple Victims Advertised
sections.text: Some advertisements advertise multiple women at the same time. We consider the presence of more than one victim as potential evidence of organized trafficking [6].

sections.heading: 3.1.5 Victim Weight
sections.text: This information is particularly useful when considering that lower body weights (under 115 lbs) are mostly correlated with smaller and underage girls [2,30] and thus with human trafficking.

sections.heading: 4 Semi-Supervised Learning Framework
sections.text: Here we first present some preliminary notations that are necessary for the rest of the discussion, and then outline our proposed Semi-Supervised Concept = = S3VM − R, to detect online human trafficking. Note: Our framework is an extension of the existing Laplacian SVM [14]. In particular, we will reiterate that our current research does not use additional information from the standard Laplacian SVM to use the additional information from our first feature shelf graph and then solve the related optimization problem. [15].4.1 Technical PreliminariesWe assume a set of l-designated pairs. (xi, yi) li = 1 and an unlabeled set of u-instances {xl + i} ui = 1, where xi-Rn and yi-1}.

sections.heading: 5 Experimental Study
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Blind Evaluation
sections.text: For the next set of experiments, we first perform our method on the entire filtered data set and without mutual validation; recall from the previous sections, which is to make better use of the unmarked examples; then the following control experiment was conducted; our learner was tested on the entire set of unmarked examples; from 3,343 instances, our approach identified two sets of positive and negative instances; the positive sentence contained 394 advertising campaigns that were likely to be of interest to law enforcement, while the negative sentence included the remaining 2,962 unmarked examples of likely to be of less interest to law enforcement; next, we pinpoint the correctly identified factions of these two sets; we selected two subgroups (control groups) of 100 examples each for further validation by our experts; we passed these two control groups to our experts for further verification; and the expert-validated results showed that all examples in the positive group were of interest to law enforcement, while only two examples were not correctly classified from the negative group.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this study, which focused on textual information from the available data searched by Backpage.com, we identified whether escort advertising could reflect the activities of trafficking in human beings. In particular, we first proposed an unmonitored filtering approach to filter out the data more likely to be involved in trafficking in human beings. We then proposed a semi-supervised learner, namely S3VM − R, and trained him on a small portion of the data handlabeled by a trafficking expert. We used the trained model for identifying invisible data labels. The results suggested that our approach is effective in identifying potential trafficking-related advertising. Our future plans include replicating the study by integrating more interesting features, especially those supported by the criminal literature. As labeling unlabeled examples is costly, it would be an interesting direction of research to enable active, supervised learning to become less active with the data we normally query the normal user data, in particular.

sections.heading: 7 Competing Interests
sections.text: The authors declare that they have no competing interests.

sections.heading: 8 Authors’ Contributions
sections.text: HA developed and implemented the human trafficking detection approach and drafted the manuscript. PS guided through the entire project and revised the manuscript. JS was in contact with a law enforcement expert who was responsible for hand marking parts of the data. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

sections.heading: Acknowledgment
sections.text: This work was funded by the Find Me Group, a 501 (c) 3 dedicated to the resolution and closure of families of missing persons, and the authors would like to thank anonymous reviewers for their valuable suggestions to improve the quality of the essay.

referenceMentions.context: Before the advent of the Internet, human traffickers were under risks of being arrested by law enforcement while advertising their victims on streets [4].
However, move to the Internet has made it easier and less dangerous for sex sellers [5] as they no longer needed to advertise on the streets.

Although the Internet has presented new trafficking related challenges for law enforcement, it has also provided readily and publicly available rich source of information which could be gleaned from online sex advertisements for fighting this crime [6].

, learning from labeled and unlabeled examples, is still one of the most interesting yet challenging problems in the machine learning community [14].
In this article, expanding on our previous work [15], we use the data crawled from the adult entertainment section of the website Backpage.
com and extend the existing Laplacian SVM framework [14] to detect escort advertisements of high interest to law enforcement.
We extended the Laplacian SVM [14] and proposed the semi-supervised support vector machine learning algorithm, SVM − R.
Recently, several studies have examined the role of the Internet and related technology in facilitating human trafficking [16,17,18].
Recently, several studies have examined the role of the Internet and related technology in facilitating human trafficking [16,17,18].
Recently, several studies have examined the role of the Internet and related technology in facilitating human trafficking [16,17,18].
For example, the work of [16] studied how closely sex trafficking is intertwined with new technologies.
According to [17], sexual exploitation of women and children is a global human right crisis that is being escalated by the use of new technologies.

For instance, findings from a group of experts from the Council of Europe demonstrated that the Internet and sex industry are closely interlinked and volume and content of the material on the Internet promoting human trafficking are unprecedented [18].
One of the earliest works which leveraged data mining techniques for online human trafficking was [18], wherein the authors conducted data analysis on the adult section of the website Backpage.
In a similar attempt, other studies [19,20]
In a similar attempt, other studies [19,20]

The work of [19] for instance, concluded that large events such as the Super Bowl which attract significant amount of concentration of people in a relatively short period of time and in a confined urban area, could be a desirable location for sex traffickers to bring their victims for commercial sexual exploitation.

Similarly, the data-driven approach of [20] showed that in some but not all events, one can see a correlation between occurrence of the event and statistically significant evidence of an influx of sex trafficking activity.

Also, certain studies [21] have tried to build large distributed systems to store and process available online human trafficking data in order to perform entity resolution and create ontological relations between entities.
Beyond these works, the work of [22] studied the problem of isolating sources of human trafficking from online advertisements with a pairwise entity resolution approach.
Another work of [6] used Backpage.

The work of [23] also deployed machine learning for the advertisement classification problem, by training a supervised learning classifier on labeled data (based on phone numbers of known traffickers) provided by a victim advocacy group.

We note that our semi-supervised approach can also be used as a complementary method to procedures such as those described in [23] as we can significantly expand the training set for use with supervised learning.
Finally, note that our current research is different from our previous work [15] and we list the key nuances here:

To obtain such dataset, we use the same raw data from [15], but this time with slight modifications of the thresholds that were used for filtering out less likely human trafficking related advertisements.

– In this paper we present a new framework based on the existing Laplacian SVM [14], by adding a regularization term to the standard optimization problem and solving the new optimization equation derived from there.
In contrast, [15] utilized the off-the-shelf graph based semi-supervised learner, LabelSpreading method [24], without any further manipulation of the original approach.
In contrast, [15] utilized the off-the-shelf graph based semi-supervised learner, LabelSpreading method [24], without any further manipulation of the original approach.
– Unlike [15] in which we did not compare our method with other approaches, this work compares our proposed framework against other semi-supervised and supervised learners.

Since the Kolmogorov complexity is not computable, we approximate the complexity of an advertisement content by first removing stop words and then computing entropy of the content [25].
We use the following equation [31] to calculate the entropy of the content and thus approximate the Kolmogorov complexity of X:
This particular choice is because of the fact that character-level n-grams have already shown to be useful in detecting unwanted content for spam detection [26].

Note one typical value for the smoothness penalty coefficient Cs is γI (l+u)2 , where 1 (l+u)2 is a natural scale factor for empirical estimate of the Laplace operator and γI is a regularization term [14].

In this study, we leverage textual data from the website “Backpage”– used for classified advertisement– to discern potential patterns of human trafficking activities which manifest online and identify advertisements of high interest to law enforcement. We train the proposed method using labeled and unlabeled data and evaluate it on a fraction of the unlabeled data, herein referred to as unseen data, with our expert’s further verification. Results from comparisons between our method and other semi-supervised and supervised approaches on the labeled data demonstrate that our learner is effective in identifying advertisements of high interest to law enforcement.
